prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Spatial resolution: Our sample is at a distance of 1-4.5 kpc, and we aim to resolve individual envelopes at sizes of ~1000-3000 AU. This can be achieved with 0.6" angular resolution corresponding to 600-3000 AU spatial resolution.
Spectral setup: We aim to cover the 7.5 GHz bandwidth available (Fig.2) at a spectral resolution of 1.12 MHz. Baseband4 (333.5-335.3 GHz) is the most line-free band for the continuum. Baseband3 (335.3-337.2 GHz) covers the C17O (3-2) line and several CH3OH transitions. Baseband2 (345.3-347.1 GHz) covers the CO (3-2) line, as well as H13CN(4-3), HC3N (38-37), SO (8-7), H13CO+(4-3). Baseband1 (347.1-349.05) covers the SiO (8-7), HN13C (4-3), H2CS (10-9) lines.
Sensitivity: The continuum is correlated at 345 GHz in a 7.5 GHz bandwidth, together with key molecular tracers to distinguish between pre-/protostellar fragments. We therefore first argue for the line sensitivity and justify that it fulfills our continuum requests (see below).
Line: Our APEX CO (3-2) mapping indicates emission in the line wings (up to 20-30 km/s off from the vlsr) at an average 3.6 Jy/beam (~0.1 K in the 19.2" beam). Assuming an elongated morphology extending in a ~10"x2" area (estimated from similar objects in Duarte-Cabral et al. 2013) and a uniform distribution in a 0.6" beam we expect to see (emission area/beam area) ~50 mJy emission. For a 5 S/N detection therefore 10mJy 1sigma noise level is requested at the finest (1.12 MHz, 1.2 km/s) spectral resolution. We note, that the S/N can be increased by smoothing up to 2-3 km/s for the CO (3-2) line. This sensitivity is reached in ~3min integration time per source according to the OT. In addition, Our APEX/FLASH mapping indicates compact emission for the SiO (8-7) and SO lines (with wings and an intensity above 0.5~K Tmb), therefore we will very likely detect the peak emission of these lines as well. We correlate the 7.5~GHz bandwidth available to look for tracers of hot-core like emission, which should be boosted in the small beam.
Continuum: We target the brightest sources from ATLASGAL, so our sample has a peak flux >5 Jy/19.2"beam of APEX at 345 GHz. We account for a pessimistic 98% flux loss for a protocluster with substantial fragmentation and a dominating amount of extended dust emission, which reduces the expected peak flux to 0.1 Jy/0.6" beam. Accounting for a dynamic range of ~100, we will be sensitive to 1 mJy fragments corresponding to sub solar mass envelopes at 4.5 kpc. A 0.2 mJy 1sigma continuum sensitivity is the pessimistic lower limit on the requested sensitivity, since likely the achievable dynamic range is going to dictate the final noise level. This sensitivity is reached in the above requested integration time considering up to 60% line contamination in the band.
ACA: See below.
Imaging: According to our simulations (Fig.3.) the requested ~3min/source integration time will be sufficient for a high fidelity imaging. The dust peak positions are known to an accuracy of 2-3" from ATLASGAL, therefore mosaicing is not necessary.
Special constrains: high overheads for a sample of bright sources is not avoidable. Our sample is complete to the justified mass limit.

We expect line-widths > 3 km/s. The requested correlator setup is a compromise between 1) continuum sensitivity 2) spectral coverage 3) spectral resolution. With the requested setup we still resolve most the lines with at least 3 channels (also confirmed in the APEX and ACA data).

We use the same spectral setup as in our 72% completed Cycle 2 project. Statistics of the large sample requires homogenous dataset, therefore to stay consistent with those observations we prefer to keep the current spectral setup.

Spatial resolution: The sample is located between 1-4 kpc, and we aim to resolve individual collapsing envelopes at sizes of ~1000-3000 AU (e.g. Bontemps et al. 2010). This can be achieved with the C34-2 configuration providing a moderate angular resolution of 0.59", corresponding to 590-2400 AU spatial resolution. In Cycle 2 we have obtained the ACA and TP observations (with APEX) to recover emission from the largest angular scales.
The ACA observations for this project have been completed in Cycle 2.

Spectral setup: We aim to cover the 7.5 GHz bandwidth available (Fig.2) at a spectral resolution of 1.12 MHz. Baseband4 (333.5-335.3 GHz) is the most line-free band for the continuum. Baseband3 (335.3-337.2 GHz) covers the C17O (3-2) line and several CH3OH transitions. Baseband2 (345.3-347.1 GHz) covers the CO (3-2) line, as well as H13CN(4-3), HC3N (38-37), SO (8-7), H13CO+(4-3). We expect line-widths > 3 km/s. The requested correlator setup is a compromise between 1) continuum sensitivity 2) spectral coverage 3) spectral resolution. With the requested setup we will still resolve most the lines with at least 3 channels (also confirmed in the APEX and ACA data).

We use the same spectral setup as in our 72% completed Cycle 2 project. Statistics of the large sample requires homogenous dataset, therefore to stay consistent with those observations we prefer to keep the current spectral setup.

Spatial resolution: The sample is located between 1-4 kpc, and we aim to resolve individual collapsing envelopes at sizes of ~1000-3000 AU (e.g. Bontemps et al. 2010). This can be achieved with the C34-2 configuration providing a moderate angular resolution of 0.59", corresponding to 590-2400 AU spatial resolution. In Cycle 2 we have obtained the ACA and TP observations (with APEX) to recover emission from the largest angular scales.
The ACA observations for this project have been completed in Cycle 2.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The origin of stars, in particular massive stars, is a fundamental open question in astrophysics. Pre-ALMA interferometric studies reveal precursors to early B to late O type stars with collapsing envelopes of 15-20Msol in 1000-3000AU. There are exceptionally few examples known to date of more massive envelopes at these size-scales. Do massive collapsing envelopes exist within this size-scale up to the 100msol regime? Do they form the same way as the so far observed 8-20 Msol regime? To answer these questions a statistical sample is the necessary next step. Here we target a well characterized sample of massive and cold clumps above 650 Msol within 4.5 kpc identified by the ATLASGAL survey in order to reveal the most massive individual collapsing envelopes on 3000 AU size scales (with 0.6" angular resolution). We will drastically increase the number of 20-100 Msol envelopes known to date. We also target molecular tracers to distinguish between pre-stellar and protostellar condensations allowing statistical life-time estimates for the elusive pre-stellar phase. This is a resubmission of a Cycle 2 project, in case it would not be completed (current status is 72% complete).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00960.S The first Galaxy-scale hunt for the earliest phases of the formation of the most massive stars PI: Csengeri
